categories.title: Basic Grammar
categories.subtitle: Essential German grammar rules with detailed explanations

items.explanation: Unlike English, every German noun has a grammatical gender (masculine, feminine, or neuter) that determines its article. Memorizing the gender with each noun is essential.
items.example: Der Mann, die Frau, das Kind. (The man, the woman, the child.)
items.tips: Some patterns can help: male people use 'der', female people use 'die', and diminutives ending in -chen or -lein use 'das'.

items.explanation: Indefinite articles in German also change based on the gender of the noun they accompany.
items.example: Ein Mann, eine Frau, ein Kind. (A man, a woman, a child.)
items.tips: The indefinite article for both masculine and neuter nouns is 'ein', while for feminine nouns it's 'eine'.

items.explanation: Personal pronouns in German change form based on case. These are the nominative (subject) forms for singular persons.
items.example: Ich bin, du bist, er/sie/es ist. (I am, you are, he/she/it is.)
items.tips: The conjugation of verbs changes for each pronoun, similar to English 'I am' vs 'he is'.

items.explanation: These are the plural personal pronouns in the nominative case. 'Sie' (capitalized) is also the formal 'you' for both singular and plural.
items.example: Wir sind, ihr seid, sie sind. (We are, you are, they are.)
items.tips: Always capitalize 'Sie' when it means the formal 'you' to distinguish it from 'sie' (she/they).

items.explanation: Used for current actions, habits, and general truths. The present tense in German can also express future actions with a time reference.
items.example: Ich lerne Deutsch. (I am learning German.) / Ich fahre morgen nach Berlin. (I'm going to Berlin tomorrow.)
items.tips: Regular verbs follow predictable patterns, but many common verbs are irregular.

items.explanation: The most common past tense in spoken German, formed with a helping verb (haben/sein) + past participle. The participle goes to the end of the sentence.
items.example: Ich habe Deutsch gelernt. (I have learned German.) / Sie ist nach Hause gegangen. (She went home.)
items.tips: Most verbs use 'haben', but verbs of motion and state change use 'sein'.

items.explanation: Used mainly in written German and for certain common verbs like 'sein' (to be), 'haben' (to have), and modal verbs in spoken language.
items.example: Ich war in Berlin. (I was in Berlin.) / Er hatte keine Zeit. (He had no time.)
items.tips: In conversation, Germans often use Perfekt instead of Präteritum, except for these common verbs.

items.explanation: Generally, 'nicht' comes at the end of a simple sentence or before the element being negated. For negating nouns, use 'kein/keine' instead.
items.example: Ich verstehe nicht. (I don't understand.) / Das ist nicht mein Buch. (That is not my book.) / Ich habe keine Zeit. (I don't have time.)
items.tips: Word order is crucial: 'nicht' typically comes after the verb and before adjectives or adverbs.

items.explanation: Yes/no questions invert the subject and verb. The verb comes first, followed by the subject.
items.example: Sprichst du Deutsch? (Do you speak German?) / Ist das dein Auto? (Is that your car?)
items.tips: The intonation rises at the end of the question, similar to English.

items.explanation: Questions that start with interrogative words (wer, was, wo, wann, warum, wie). The W-word comes first, then the verb, then the subject.
items.example: Wo wohnst du? (Where do you live?) / Was machst du heute? (What are you doing today?)
items.tips: The most common W-words are: wer (who), was (what), wo (where), wann (when), warum (why), wie (how).

items.explanation: Used for the subject of a sentence and after certain verbs like 'sein' (to be).
items.example: Der Mann ist alt. (The man is old.) / Ich bin eine Studentin. (I am a student.)
items.tips: Articles in the nominative: der (masc.), die (fem.), das (neut.), die (plural)

items.explanation: Used for the direct object of a sentence and after certain prepositions (durch, für, gegen, ohne, um).
items.example: Ich sehe den Mann. (I see the man.) / Ich kaufe ein Buch. (I'm buying a book.)
items.tips: Only masculine articles change in the accusative: 'der' becomes 'den', but 'die' and 'das' stay the same.

items.explanation: Used for the indirect object and after certain prepositions (aus, bei, mit, nach, seit, von, zu).
items.example: Ich gebe dem Kind ein Buch. (I give the child a book.) / Ich helfe meiner Mutter. (I help my mother.)
items.tips: Articles change to: dem (masc.), der (fem.), dem (neut.), den + n (plural)

items.explanation: Used to show possession and after certain prepositions (während, wegen, trotz).
items.example: Das Auto des Mannes ist rot. (The man's car is red.) / Wegen des Regens bleibe ich zu Hause. (Because of the rain, I'm staying at home.)
items.tips: Articles change to: des (masc.), der (fem.), des (neut.), der (plural). Masculine and neuter nouns typically add -s or -es.

items.explanation: Express ability, permission, obligation, etc. (können, dürfen, müssen, sollen, wollen, mögen). They push the main verb to the end of the sentence in its infinitive form.
items.example: Ich kann Deutsch sprechen. (I can speak German.) / Du musst jetzt gehen. (You must go now.)
items.tips: Modal verbs have irregular conjugations and are often used in the simple past (Präteritum) even in spoken German.

items.explanation: Used to give orders or instructions. Forms differ for du, ihr, and Sie.
items.example: Komm hier! (Come here! - informal singular) / Kommt hier! (Come here! - informal plural) / Kommen Sie hier! (Come here! - formal)
items.tips: For 'du' commands, drop the -st ending and sometimes the final -e. For 'ihr', use the present tense form without the pronoun.
